title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this legislation. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina are descendants of coastal tribes, recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956. The Lumbee Indians, descendants of coastal tribes in North Carolina, were recognized by Congress in 1956 but were not granted full federal recognition and benefits. Now, Congress acknowledges that the Lumbee Tribe should receive full federal recognition and the accompanying benefits. The Act of June 7, 1956 is amended to provide full federal recognition to the Lumbee Tribe, granting them benefits. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services available to other Indian tribes. Non-enrolled Indians in specific counties can petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be living on or near a reservation for service delivery purposes. The Secretary verifies needs and budget for the tribe. Members of the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina residing in certain counties are considered to be living on or near an Indian reservation for service delivery. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services work with the tribe to determine needs and budget for eligible services. The Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, develop a determination of needs and budget for eligible services. This includes submitting a written statement of needs and a budget to Congress after verifying the tribal roll. The Secretaries of the Interior and Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, will submit a written statement of needs and budget to Congress after verifying the tribal roll for the delivery of Federal services. The tribal roll, as of the date of enactment, will define the service population of the Tribe, subject to verification by the Secretary of the Interior. Verification will confirm compliance with membership criteria in the Tribe's constitution within 1 year of enactment. The Tribe seeks to convey fee land to the United States to be held in trust within Robeson County, North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior will treat the land as on-reservation trust acquisitions. Additionally, state jurisdiction is addressed in the following section. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept transfers of land from the state to the United States. The Secretary of the Interior may accept transfers of jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina to the United States on behalf of the Lumbee Tribe, with a two-year waiting period after the agreement is effective. The Lumbee Tribe can transfer jurisdiction from the State of North Carolina to the United States under an agreement, with a two-year waiting period before it takes effect. This transfer will not affect the application of the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
